Canonical Forms

Definition. A canonical form for a 2×22\times 22×2 matrix includes the following:

  1. an enlargement along the axes [λ100λ2]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix}[λ1​0​0λ2​​],
  2. a shear [λ10λ]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​1λ​], and
  3. scalar multiples of the identity matrix [λ00λ]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​0λ​].

Theorem. All 2×22\times 22×2 matrices are similar to one of the above canonical forms.

Proof.

Which canonical form the matrix is similar to depends on its eigenvalues: whether it has two identical eigenvalues, or two distinct eigenvalues. Let AAA be the 2×22\times 22×2 matrix in question, and let λ1,λ2\lambda_1, \lambda_2λ1​,λ2​ be its two eigenvalues; we thus have either λ1=λ2\lambda_1 = \lambda_2λ1​=λ2​, or λ1≠λ2\lambda_1 \neq \lambda_2λ1​=λ2​ (note that two eigenvalues, not necessarily real are guaranteed to exist by the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra).

Case 1. λ1≠λ2\lambda_1 \neq \lambda_2λ1​=λ2​. As different eigenvalues correspond to different eigenvectors, and different eigenvectors are linearly independent, AAA must be diagonalizable as its eigenvectors span F2\mathbb{F}^2F2. As such, it is similar to [λ100λ2]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix}[λ1​0​0λ2​​].

Case 2. λ1=λ2=λ\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 = \lambdaλ1​=λ2​=λ. The matrix is either (i) diagonalizable if the eigenvalue is not defective, or (ii) not diagonalizable. If the matrix is diagonalizable, then from our study of diagonalization, it is similar to [λ00λ]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}[λ0​0λ​] and we are done. However, if the matrix is not diagonalizable, λ\lambdaλ must be defective, indicating that

(A−λI)x=0(A-\lambda I)\mathbf{x} = 0(A−λI)x=0

has a solution space of dimension 1. (It cannot have dimension 0 because Ax=λxA\mathbf{x} = \lambda\mathbf{x}Ax=λx by definition for another x\mathbf{x}x besides the zero vector; this is guaranteed by det⁡(A−λI)=0\det(A - \lambda I) = 0det(A−λI)=0). Let the vector v\mathbf{v}v span the eigenspace EλE_{\lambda}Eλ​ and construct (v,w)(\mathbf{v,w})(v,w) spanning F2\mathbb{F}^2F2 by selecting w\mathbf{w}w as linearly independent to v\mathbf{v}v. Suppose that

Remark. The matrices [λ100λ2]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 \end{bmatrix}[λ1​0​0λ2​​] and [λ200λ1]\begin{bmatrix} \lambda_2 & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_1 \end{bmatrix}[λ2​0​0λ1​​] are similar by means of the transformation matrix [0110]\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}[01​10​].

Remark. It is possible to derive simiar canonical forms, or Jordan normal forms, for any complex n×nn\times nn×n matrix; specifically, all square matrices AAA are similar to a canonical form A~\tilde{A}A~ satisfying

A~ii=λi, A~i(i+1)∈{1,0}, 0 otherwise\tilde{A}_{ii} = \lambda_i,\ \tilde{A}_{i(i+1)} \in \{1, 0\}, \text{ 0 otherwise}A~ii​=λi​, A~i(i+1)​∈{1,0}, 0 otherwise

i.e. the elements on the diagonal are the eigenvalues, the elements on the superdiagonal (one above the diagonal) are one or zero, and all other elements are zero.
